headline: Don’t recommend anyone young / ambitious to join
pros:
This company doesn’t really sack people, so even if you perform badly, your bonus is still stable.

You don’t have to work hard for this company, because your compensation package and promotion path wouldn’t change much anyway
cons:
- A very French-centric company, that means all - key decisions and information are only available from France, so it’s very limited on what you can do, you feel very helpless when there is no response/support from Paris, which happened very often

If you are young and you have ambitions, this company is not for you, go to investment banks / hedge funds instead for a much better package

The so-called trainee program only offered 1 year contract role to graduates, with only 7 days of AL and significantly lower salary than other management trainee programs organised by banks. There is no future to be a trainee here, they don’t grow you and only use you for cheap labour only.

The management culture of the Hong Kong office is very local and it’s not a MNC. No work from home is allowed once the government resumed working from office , which is probably the only FI had such a practice. Besides, there was no allowance given to employees to wfh. You also need to clock in and clock out because the HR generates a record to see who is late for work.

headline: OK, not great, not the worst

- Nice office

cons:
- Culture can be toxic
- High employee turnover
- Salary, profit share and bonus is below market - keen on maintaining a specific cost/income ratio - very skewed pay distribution 
- Nepotism, you won't be hired on the basis of merit - some very questionable hires in relatively senior positions where skill/knowledge doesn't match job role and would not happen at a decent firm, it also helps if you are French and you have a personal relationship with the CEO 
- Progression for young people is non-existent, they prefer to hire young people on rotation rather than build young people to lead the business

headline: Experience will depend on the team you work in, very bureacratic and big gender wage gaps
pros: Amundi is known in the Asset Management industry to have some of the nicest people working there, but that's not saying much. If you don't care for stimulation, want a decent wage, and 25 days holiday then this might be the place for you. People start at 9, leave at 6, and have an hour lunch -not very taxing for Finance. Benefits are good: Denplan, Bupa, 25 days holiday.
cons: Don't accept a job here if you are ambitious and want to move up the career ladder quickly, as there are few positions that open up. Decisions are made in HQ in Paris, and you're essentially just expected to execute them -no matter your thoughts on the matter. They always throw more people at a problem, rather than solving the issue (which is often to do with their technology -which is notoriously a disgrace). A prime example is that they decided to build their own CRM system instead of paying for Salesforce, at the detriment to the Sales' productivity as it doesn't perform basic functions. I found out that my male colleague, who spent his day on Facebook, was paid at least 50% more than me.

headline: Good workplace

headline: Good and bad - Mainly bad though.
pros:
- Relaxed schedule
- Nice management
- Ok pay for first couple years out of school
- 3% 401k Match
- Lots of PTO
- Nice co workers
cons:
Middle management strives for mediocrity. When middle management / people in Business Development screw up there is absolutely NO ACCOUNTABILITY to own or correct the problem. Working in sales is really hard when marketing and compliance aren't given the correct headcounts to actually get things done. Expect to not have proper marketing material for reps you're working with for 1-2 months into the following quarter, secondly don't expect to get an annual review because it take 4-5 months into the next year to get that done. HR tends to set the pay expectation fairly on target but management in sales will set a very different (higher) expectation. Frankly the overall feeling across the entire team is very low right now and needs some work. A lot of potential to be better but people need to not get sacrificed for being honest about how the environment actually feels. If you express dissatisfaction it will be swept under the rug and pretend it was never said. Secondly expect your quarterly "manager discretion" bonuses to drop because you were honest.

Lastly - Amundi is basically cutting funding to the Americas, although they need a certain headcount they're basically waiting for the bottom to fall out so they can justify not needing the distribution channel down the road because it isn't as profitable as it once was.

headline: Beware of leadership
pros: A leader with scope and depth that can provide good short-term opportunities for some. A great place to work for french freemasons (but if you are one you do not need glassdoor).

Unless you share this special culture and background you will never be part of decision-making (see other contributions about unstable organization, management, shifting directions). If you can, use your network to learn about middle and top-management many depression and yes suicide cases.

headline: Very hierarchised
pros: Nice people; located in Montparnasse; nice infirmary
cons: Horrible management: being on time is more important than the work; everybody fights to spend their budget at the end of the year so as not to lose it; the SI teams are slow and always overbooked; everyone is overworked but no one is at work after 7pm; nobody questions the CEO; my N+2 talked to me twice in one year; offices are in 5 different locations, the cafeteria is underground; human ressources couldn't give me an appointment within four weeks; problems with your team manager are adressed once a year during evaluation - the rest of the time, you have to pretend everything is great; i had a dental emergency when i pulled out a bleeding molar and I had to take an afternoon off to go to the dentist (as my team leader told me, it was exceptional he was giving it to me on such short notice)
